summary: the rapid emergence of several new drug-resistant viruses necessitates the development of new treatment modalities (Moscona, 2005), including effective chemotherapeutic agents. traditional medicine has relieve the symptoms of various diseases including cancer and infectious diseases. EF has long been used for the management of fever, edema, and chills. EF is reported to possess anti-oxidant, anti-diabetic, and anti-bacterial activities. EF is reported to have anti-metastatic and anti-angiogenic effects on malignant human cancer cells. Influenza A/PuertoRico/8/34 H1N1, green fluorescent protein (GFP)-tagged Influenza A/PuertoRico/8/34 H1N1 (PR8-GFP) and NDV-GFP were propagated in the allantoic fluid of 10-day-old chicken embryos. cells were seeded in 12-well plates and incubated for 12 h. cells were infected with recombinant mouse interferon (IFN-) or DMEM with 100 g/mL WEF. the cells then were infected with PR8-GFP (MOI 1), NDV-GFP (MOI 2) and VSV-GFP (MOI 1). primer sequences for quantitative real-time RT-PCR were calculated using the Ct method and -actin (internal reference) to normalized mRNA expression levels (Choi et al., 2016). cells were incubated at 37°C with 5% CO2 for 24 h. after 24 h, cells were washed with cold PBS and fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde for 30 min at RT. cells were permeabilized with 1% Triton X-100 in TBS for 15 min at RT. protein bands were visualized using a chemiluminescent reagent (Thermo Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA) and -actin (Cell Signaling Technology, Boston, MA, USA) the relative intensities of protein bands were measured using Image J. ionization mode, positive; Identification and quantitation of phytochemicals in water extract of Eupatorium fortunei. the expression pattern of the influenza A virus gene HA was confirmed by qRT-PCR. the expression pattern of the influenza A virus gene HA was confirmed. 15 components were treated at a concentration of 0.2 g/mL. the expression of influenza A virus HA mRNA was lower than that of untreated cells after treatment with quercetin (0.81-fold), psoralen (0.314-fold), or quercitrin (0.334-fold) quercetin, psoralen, or quercitrin (0.2 g/mL) and IFN- (1,000 U/mL) 12 h before infection with PR8-GFP (MOI 1). the antiviral effect was verified after 24 h of viral infection as the presence or absence of GFP expression. the synthesis of influenza mRNA for M2, NP, PA, PB2 and NS-1 was dramatically suppressed in quercetin-treated cells than in psoralen- and quercitrin-treated cells and in untreated cells. we investigated the effect of quercetin, psoralen, and quercitrin on IFN- secretion, as measured by ELISA. pro-inflammatory cytokines and type I interferon play significant roles in inducing antiviral responses and immunoregulatory activities. we performed a screening test to identify pro-inflammatory cytokines and observed the interferon- production in traditional herbal medicines. DMEM containing 10% FBS alone, 1,000 unit/mL recombinant mouse IFN-, or 100 g/mL WEF and incubated at 37°C with 5% CO2. supernatant from each group was harvested at 12 and 24 h and clarified by centrifugation at 2,500 g for 10 min at 4°C. WEF treatment significantly reduced the viral titers by nearly 4.8-, and 4.2-folds against GFP-expressing VSV, and PR8, respectively, at 24 hpi. compared with untreated cells, WEF-treated cells displayed significantly less cell death following infection with all tested viruses. the antiviral effect was verified after 24 h of viral infection as the presence or absence of GFP expression. UPLC-MS/MS analysis compared retention time and mass fragmentation of authentic standards identified the components of WEF. psoralen (1), angelicin (2), rutin (3), quercitrin (4), isoquercitirin (5), quercetin (6), neochlorogenic acid (7), chlorogenic acid (8) syringin (9), caffeic acid (10), 1,3-dicaffeoylquinic acid (11), p-coumaric acid (12), ferulic acid (13), o-coumaric acid (14), Quercitrin 0.002 5 11.80 465.10275 465.10303 C21H20O12 0.116 303.04980, 145.04956 Isoquercitrin 0.009 6 15.85 303.04993 303.04987 C15H10O7 0.212 285.03949, 155.04890, 153.01811, 109.02841 Quercetin 0.008 PHENOLICS 7 6.72 35 antiviral activity of the 15 identified WEF components We first tested the antiviral activity of 15 components from WEF. expression pattern of the influenza A virus gene HA was confirmed by qRT-PCR. expression of M2 protein in RAW 264.7 cells was suppressed in cells treated with quercetin than in those treated with psoralen or untreated cells. the antiviral effect was verified after 24 h of viral infection. atants from each group were harvested at 24 h, clarified, and dispensed into murine IFN-, TNF-, and IL-6 capture antibody-coated ELISA plates to measure cytokine secretion. we further investigated whether quercetin, psoralen, and quercitrin treatment inhibits viral mRNA (M2, NP, PA, PB2 and NS-1) synthesis. itrin showed significantly inhibited viral replication and induced cytokine secretion, such as IFN-beta. occurrence of viral infection mainly occurs in a state of deteriorated immune function. new infectious diseases, such as avian influenza virus, have emerged. WEF treatment induces high levels of IL-6, IFN-, and TNF- secretion. we also observed that WEF treatment induces increased phosphorylation of IRF3, STAT1 and TBK1 relative to untreated cells after 12 h. the genus Eupatorium (family Asteraceae) is known to include 1,200 species in the world. it is known to have many biological activities including anti-nociceptive, anti-inflammatory, antibacterial, antifungal, anticancer, antiplasmodial, antioxidative, and immunomodulating properties. euparin from E. buniifolium exhibits antiviral activities against poliovirus type 1 (Visintini Jaime et al., 2013) and pseudorabies virus strain RC/79 (Zanon et al., 1999) essential oils of E. patens inactivates HSV-1 and VSV. WEF or its components, including quercetin, psoralen, and quercitrin, can be useful as therapeutic or preventive agents to limit viral replication. authors declare that the research was conducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could be construed as a potential conflict of interest.
